text:
One more perception-vs-reality component of the scream: Dean didn't lose the Dem nomination because of the scream. 

“We took third that day,” Joe Trippi told me. 

Dean added for this story: “What did in our candidacy was ourselves."
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
But there was another story behind Dean's scream: It played much differently to those in attendance -- including yours truly -- versus those who saw it on TV. 

Reason: The mic for the TV cameras drowned out the rowdy crowd.

And I remember Tom Harkin more fired up than Dean!
author: mmurraypolitics

text: A president running for re-election wants to talk about accomplishments. Outside of health care, the stimulus and bin Laden, Obama's biggest first-term achievements happened in that lame duck
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
One of the underappreciated parts of Obama's re-election in 2012 was the productivity during the lame-duck session of 2010. 

Payroll tax cuts. End of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell." New START treaty. 

The question for Trump: Just how lame will his lame duck be? http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/just-how-lame-will-lame-duck-session-be-n941116 …

text:
And that the laws of political gravity applied to Trump in 2018 provides this important lesson for 2020: Political fundamentals still matter. 

Can Trump broaden his popularity? Raise his job rating? And will the U.S. economy still be firing on all cylinders 2 years from now?

text: Three weeks later, here's one of the most consequential outcomes of the 2018 midterms: Yes, political gravity caught up to President Trump https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/2018-political-gravity-caught-trump-n940006 …

text:
As it turns out, Dem fed statewide candidates in FL, IN, MO, MT, ND and TX did as well -- or better -- than their party's performance in these states since '12. 

It just wasn't good enough for victory in FL, IN, MO, ND and TX
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Worth noting: Being on a media VP list doesn't make you a Clinton/Obama backer -- as Trump incorrectly alleged in his interview. 

McRaven, as chancellor of the University of Texas System, was neutral in the 2016 presidential race.

Murphy in 2016: 44%

Obama in 2012: 50%
Nelson in 2012: 55%
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Also, Beto's 48% in Texas and Abrams' 49% in Georgia appear to be ceilings for Dems in this Trump Era.

(And while GOV races are different animals than SEN contests, GA-GOV was more like a federal race...)
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
No, Republicans didn't "steal" Georgia's gubernatorial contest. 

Couldn't say it better than @rickhasen does here
author: mmurraypolitics

text:

Nelson in 2018: 50%
Murphy in 2016: 44%

Obama in 2012: 50%
Nelson in 2012: 55%
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Oh, and Joe Manchin got nearly 50% in his WV-SEN win -- down from his 61% in 2012. 

Bottom line: Across the country in 2018, Dems were hitting their ceilings in the Trump Era. But those ceilings weren't enough to win in the reddest of states.
author: mmurraypolitics

text: The one exception here was Jon Tester in MT, who got 50% in 2018 -- up from his 49% winning percentage in '12 (and Hillary's 35% in '16 and Obama's 42% in '12)
author: mmurraypolitics

text: But I'm not talking about margin. Am talking about same percentage of the vote (46%)
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Worth noting: The 46% McCaskill got is exactly the same as the 46% that Jason Kander got in 2016 (while Hillary Clinton got 38% in MO in '16, and Obama took 44% in '12).

text: Despite the finger-pointing in MO/ IN/ND, the only federal statewide Dems who performed better than McCaskill, Donnelly & Heitkamp in those states going back to '12 were … McCaskill, Donnelly and Heitkamp - against *very* different candidates
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
The last major development in the Russia probe was *two months ago* on Sept. 14, when Paul Manafort pleaded guilty.

text:
Yes, voting "present" is one potential way around this for vulnerable Dems.

The question I have: Is voting "present" on Jan 3 enough protection for those who promised a new generation of leaders?
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Agreed. In totality, the GOP TV ad blitz against Pelosi failed. 

But: 16-17 of the incoming House Dem freshmen class deflected those attacks by promising to vote against Pelosi and saying they wanted new leaders. 

Those freshmen are stuck, esp if they ultimately vote for her
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
There are 2 ways Dems can get around this math:

1 Pelosi opponents vote against her in closed-door conference elections on Nov 28 -- requiring simple Dem majority - and vote for her on Jan 3

2 On Jan 3, Pelosi opponents could vote "present" - reducing magic number for majority
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
12 incoming Dem freshmen have said they won't support Pelosi as speaker. That could grow to 16 if Dems win CA-39, ME-2, NJ-3 and UT-4. 

And this doesn't include *current* members. 

If Dems end up at +38 for 2018, they can only afford 15 defections to maintain their majority.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
House Democrats are stuck -- between the option of an unpopular Pelosi as speaker who's problematic for many of the House freshmen who just won, and the option of no real Plan B.

This morning's @NBCFirstRead
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
We've gone from 2008's huge/expanded battleground map -- CO, FL, IN, IA, MI, MO, NV, NM, NH, NC, OH, PA, VA, WI (~170 EVs) ....

To 2020's early and much slimmer battleground map -- FL, ME-2, MI, NH, PA, WI (80 EVs)

And yes, AZ/GA are wildcards.

But still...

text:
If Mia Love *does* pull off the comeback after Trump said this last week -->

"Mia Love gave me no love. And she lost. Too bad. Sorry about that, Mia."

text:
Trump directly intervened in AZ-SEN (fight with Flake, who decided not to seek re-election), SC-1 (Arrington over Sanford) and KS-GOV (Kobach over Coyler).

The GOP ended up losing all 3 seats/races.

text: Russell. Garrett. Good.

text: In the end, Dem candidates focusing on health care -- more than Trump -- paid off for them.

text:
Another way to look at it: Sinema (who focused on indies, disaffected Republicans) won AZ-SEN. 

While fellow Dem David Garcia (who focused on a progressive message and called to abolish/reform ICE) lost by double-digits in AZ-GOV.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Also in @NBCFirstRead: We asked on Election Day which party made the smarter bet -- Dems focused on the middle of the electorate, or Trump/GOP focused on the base?

We got our answer in AZ-SEN https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/trump-has-remade-gop-his-own-image-it-s-costing-n935586 …

text:
To be sure, Trump's spat with Bob Corker didn't cost the GOP; Blackburn won TN-SEN easily.

And DeSantis and Kemp won or are ahead in FL-GOV and GA-GOV. 

But does anyone else think that Adam Putnam (in FL) or Casey Cagle (in GA) might have had an easier path to victory?
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
And Trump made it clear that there was no room for Kansas' incumbent governor -- Jeff Coyler -- in today's GOP.

Well, the Republican Party lost control of the governorship in Kansas
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Trump also made it clear that there was no room for a Mark Sanford in today's GOP. 

Well, the GOP lost Sanford's SC-1 congressional seat to the Democrats
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Trump made it clear that there was no place for Republicans like Jeff Flake in his GOP. 

Well, last night, the party ended up losing Flake's seat to the Democrats.

But her total fundraising ($2M) paled in comparison to the hauls that other House Dem candidates were pulling in for a single quarter.

The local infighting in this article also is striking.

Bottom line: Candidates matter...

text:
Democrats had a good midterm showing on Election Night.

But it's been even better for them in the days since then.

This morning's @NBCFirstRead
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
As we learned in 2008 and 2012, being able to win/compete in FL and OH is a position of strength in the race to 270 EVs. 

Could run the MI/PA/WI table. But there is no margin for error
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Ha, it starts ... now. 

If the past is any guide, you'll see 2020ers begin announcing/traveling/dipping toes in the next three months -- November thru January.

The question I have for any Dem 2020er: Tell me how you win FL or OH in a general?
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Also -- 

Trump's strength or weakness determined how Republicans fared across the country: GOP did well in places Trump's approval was 50%; it suffered where he was below 50%.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Short answer: It was (mostly) about Trump.

Per the exit poll, 38% said their vote was to oppose Trump; 26% said it was to express support; 33% said Trump wasn't a factor.

So the midterms, as expected, were (largely) about him...
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Democrats took the House by winning big in urban/suburban areas across the country -- from South FL and VA, to Kansas City and Dallas/Houston. 

But the GOP held the Senate by running up the score in rural/red states.

Only increasing our urban-vs-rural divide.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Not sure I'd include PA-1 or GA-GOV, where the primary differences  weren't ideological.

But I *would* include CA-50 (another loss), where Campa-Najjar beat Navy SEAL Josh Butner in the primary.

Still, last night's results weren't good news for the progressive left.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Last year's VA-GOV contest was a great predictor for what happened last night:

In '17, Ralph Northam won the state by 9pts, and Dems crushed the GOP in Northern Va. 

But the problem for Democrats is not every state -- including the FLs and OHs -- looks like VA.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
Last night wasn't a wave. It was a realignment -- with Dems crushing in urban/suburban areas and the GOP running up the score in rural/red America.

(H/t @jtuckermartin)

text:
So when we talk about Trump's surprise win in 2016, it was aided -- in addition to Comey and Russia intervention -- by a candidate promising his opponent was engaged in the "biggest political scandal since Watergate."

Video montage:
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Wilmington, NC on Nov 5, 2016: "If she were to win, it would create an unprecedented constitutional crisis. If she ever got into the Oval Office, Hilary and her special interests would rob this country blind, you've seen what's happened."
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Wilmington, OH on Nov 4, 2016: "Hillary has engaged in a criminal massive enterprise and cover-ups like probably nobody ever before."
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Orlando, FL on Nov 2, 2016: "Hillary is likely to be under investigation for many years, probably concluding in a criminal trial."
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Miami, FL on Nov 2, 2016: "If Hillary Clinton were to be elected, it would create an unprecedented and protracted constitutional crisis. Haven't we just been through a lot with the Clintons, right?"
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Golden, CO on Oct 29, 2016: "Hillary has nobody to blame but herself for her mounting legal troubles. Her criminal action was willful, deliberate, intentional and purposeful."
author: mmurraypolitics

text: Trump in Cedar Rapids, IA on Oct 28, 2016: "The investigation is the biggest political scandal since Watergate and it's everybody's hope that justice at last can be delivered."

text:
Now *maybe* Trump was talking about the fact that GDP growth in Q1 of 2017 (when he took office) was less than GDP growth in Q4 of 2016. 

But that is not a "very tough hand"
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
By contrast, the month Obama took office (Jan 2009), the unemployment rate was 7.8%, and it would rise to 10.0% by Oct. 2009. 

What's more, in the single month of Jan 2009, the economy lost 787,000 jobs.
author: mmurraypolitics

text:
That comment, which Trump said at today's Cabinet meeting, is flat-out wrong by any objective measure. 

The month he took office (Jan 2017), the unemployment rate was 4.8% (it is now 3.8%), and there had been 76-straight months of positive job growth.
author: mmurraypolitics

author: mmurraypolitics

text: The IG also knocks the FBI for taking a month to act on the Weiner/Abedin emails (found them in late Sept 2016, didn't act until late Oct 2016)
author: mmurraypolitics

text: The IG also says Comey's Oct. 28, 2016 letter to Congress about the Weiner/Abedin emails was "a serious error of judgment" https://www.justice.gov/file/1071991/download …
author: mmurraypolitics

text: IG report on Comey's July 5, 2016 press conference: "We concluded that Comey's unilateral announcement was inconsistent with Department practice and protocol" https://www.justice.gov/file/1071991/download …
author: mmurraypolitics

text: So it appears the early conclusion of the IG report -- via Bloomberg -- is that Comey/FBI took actions that negatively impacted Hillary Clinton in 2016
